alert.note: Alert for Cook; Lake (Minnesota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Duluth (Northeast Minnesota and Northern Wisconsin)
info.headline: Snow Squall Warning issued March 11 at 1:55PM CST until March 11 at 2:30PM CST by NWS Duluth
info.description: ...A SNOW SQUALL WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 230 PM CST FOR COOK AND NORTHEASTERN LAKE COUNTIES... At 154 PM CST, a dangerous snow squall was located along a line extending from 6 miles north of Hovland, to 17 miles east of Eagle Mountain, to near Grand Marais, to 7 miles northeast of Lutsen, to 15 miles south of Little Saganaga Lake, moving southeast at 25 mph. HAZARD...Extremely poor visibility in heavy snow and blowing snow. Wind gusts up to 30 mph. SOURCE...Satellite and webcams. IMPACT...Dangerous life-threatening travel. * This includes Minnesota Highway 61 between Hovland and Tofte and the Gunflint Trail between Grand Marais and Gunflint Lake. Locations impacted include... Grand Marais, Gunflint Lake, Grand Portage, Lutsen, Hovland, Eagle Mountain, Little Saganaga Lake, Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness North of the Gunflint Trail, southeastern Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness, Pine Lake, Tom Lake, Bearskin Lake, Grand Portage Reservation, Kekekabic Lake, North Lake, Judge Magney State Park, Watab Lake, White Pine Lake, Gabimichigami Lake, and Brule Lake. PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Reduce your speed and turn on headlights! During snow squalls, the visibility may suddenly drop to near zero in whiteout conditions. There is no safe place on a highway when a snow squall hits. Visibility and traction are immediately lost in whiteout conditions, making it difficult or impossible to slow down and avoid stopped vehicles. Delay travel or safely exit the highway before the snow squall arrives.
